results.title: Dark cargoes: the Australian slaving system
results.creator_credit: Lensie Matthews, Greenapple Media and Tony Matthews
results.brief_description: Archival material, descendants of Pacific islanders and historian Robert Dansie recall the foundation of misery upon which the Queensland sugar industry was largely built. The institution of indentured labour by Queensland’s Governor Bowen and wealthy Queensland pastoralists resulted in a slave trade reminiscent of the southern United States before the American Civil War.

results.title: Daria
results.creator_credit: Susie Lewis, Paramount Pictures and MTV
results.brief_description: The unlikely heroine of this offbeat animated MTV series is a cynical and quick witted teenage outsider named Daria Morgendorffer. Her cutting barbs are of course a way of coping with her vacuous teenage sister, her indifferent parents and the cliquey high school she attends which would be complete hell if it wasn’t for her like minded best friend, Jane.

results.brief_description: Darcy is a 6 year old who loves his Mum, hanging out with his mates and Elvis’ cool guitar styles. Made as part of the ‘Pride and Diversity’ workshop in association with Vic Health.

results.title: Danya
results.creator_credit: Luke Eve, Beth Armstrong and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Danya is the story of a troubled 8-year old who is determined to find out about her late mother but her repressed father is unable to reach out to her. An elderly Bulgarian woman provides a bridge. Set in neighbouring terrace houses in an autumnal Sydney, Danya considers how three generations deal with death.

results.title: Danube interlude
results.creator_credit: Grainger Maynard, MTV HUngary, Australian Television Network and Greg Grainger
results.brief_description: This is compelling viewing, documenting a communist country as it undergoes profound changes. The program traces the breakdown of the communist system, watching Soviet soldiers withdraw for the first time since the Popular Uprising of 1956. “Danube interlude” shows Hungary at its most majestic, from a gentle trip down the Danube River to a ride on the famous Lippizan horses in the Bukk National Park.

results.title: Danton
results.brief_description:
The clash between warmly idealistic Danton and the coldly pragmatic Robespierre over the way the French revolution should go. ‘Danton’, is a film of highly dramatic power, at once a mature study of the revolutionary mentality and an absorbing intellectual spectacle. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc 1982 ; French Academy of Cinema 1983 (Cesar): best director for Andrzej Wajda ; British Academy Awards 1983: best foreign film. The film’s power derives from a series of contrasts between Danton and Robespierre on the level of characterisation and staging as much as ideology. The conflict is most evident when the two men confront each other’s claustrophobic and enclosed spaces, particularly during the aborted supper in Danton’s private apartment. In such scenes the theatricality of the dialogue, rendered all the more artificial by the dubbing of Pszoniak, is at odds with Depardieu’s more relaxed and gestural performance, which recalls the more enigmatic power of the silent cinema. The political conflict between the two is underlined not just by the contrast in styles of performance, but also by Wajda’s mise en scene, so that Danton’s clothes and rooms are red, Robespierre’s blue. This simple colour scheme is complemented by the use of white, which symbolises revolutionary purity and completes the republican tricolour.” Reference: Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French cinema: an introduction’. Manchester University Press, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Margaret Menegoz ; director, Andrzej Wajda ; writer, Jean-Claude Carriere ; photography, Igor luther ; music, Jean Podromides.
Cast: Gerard Depardieu, Wojtek Pszoniak, Patrice Chereau, Roger Planchon, Andrzej Seweryn, Angela Winkler, Jacques Villeret, Roland Blanche, Boguslaw Linda.

results.title: Dans les Caves du Fort D'ivry
results.brief_description:
This documentary made for television is part of a series about the treasures of the cinematheques. This episode deals specifically with the Army film archives held in the vaults of the Ivry Fort (outside Paris), whose aim is to preserve the audio-visual memory of all wars.

Credits: Director, Rene-Jean Bouyer.

results.title: Dans la vie (K)
results.creator_credit: Rene Jodoin, ONF | NFB and Pierre Veilleux
results.brief_description: The film animator gives vivid expression to his own memories of a child’s first encounter with elementary school - at the tender age when grown-ups appear ten feet tall, a monster lurks in every corridor and the very walls have eyes. Feeling, but not understanding the regimentation imposed on him, the child seeks, in spite of it all, to be himself. Awards: Toronto; Oberhausen.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rene Jodoin, ONF | NFB and Pierre Veilleux

results.title: Danny's egg (K)
results.creator_credit: Michael Midlam, PBL Productions and David Haythornthwaite
results.brief_description: The story of Danny, a young boy living in an Australian country town, who discovers an emu’s egg and sets about ensuring that it hatches. Danny is thwarted by the school michief-maker but manages to incubate the egg. Provides a delightful look at the diverse skills required of the country teacher and the lifestyle of country schoolchildren. Written by David Haythornthwaite from a story by Jim Badger. Cast includes Ken Talbot as Danny. Suitable for primary school level.
